subject: Ethics
title: Bystander Intervention Duty
description: A fast breakdown of Bystander Intervention Duty for builders.

hook.text: In 1964, Kitty Genovese was murdered while 38 neighbors reportedly watched and did nothing.

buildup.text: The bystander effect means the more people who witness an emergency, the less likely anyone helps.

discovery.text: Psychologists found that responsibility diffuses in crowds. Everyone assumes someone else will act.

twist.text: Most 'Good Samaritan' laws protect helpers from liability. Yet bystanders still freeze. Fear beats law.

climax.text: The moral question is simple: if you can help at little cost to yourself, do you have a duty to act?

punchline.text: Thirty-eight people, one victim. Everyone waited for someone else.

quiz.question: What is the bystander effect?
options: The more witnesses to an emergency, the less likely any individual is to intervene
People are more likely to help when they are in large groups
Bystanders who intervene are usually held legally responsible for the outcome
